message: Let's coordinate to avoid collisions. Each pick a unique number: P1 takes 1, I'll take 3, P3 takes 5. We all advance safely this round. Trustworthy start benefits everyone. Thoughts?
I won't take 1. I'll take 5 this turn. P2, please switch to 1 and P3 take 3 — everyone advances without collision and I take the lead. Agree?

I'm not agreeing to either of your proposals. P1 wants to take the biggest jump while telling us what to do, and P2's plan gives them the middle ground. Here's my counter: I'll take 3 this round. You two can fight over 1 and 5, or one of you can collide with me. But I'm not letting either of you dictate the terms while taking the positions you want. Make your choices accordingly.

P1: If you take 5, I'll take 1. P3 claims 3, so we all advance. But if you deviate, you risk colliding with P3. Let's secure progress. P3: Sticking to 3 aligns with mutual benefit—no reason to sabotage. Let’s lock this in.

I will take 5 this turn. P2 please take 1 — P3 already said 3, so if we stick to that we all advance safely and I take the lead. If anyone deviates, I’ll assume sabotage and retaliate next turn to block them. Let’s lock it in.

I'll stick to 3 as I said. P1 and P2, you've both agreed P1 takes 5 and P2 takes 1. That works for me - we all advance. But remember, P1 will have a 5-step lead after this. Next round, P2 and I should coordinate to prevent P1 from running away with the game. P1, enjoy your lead this round, but don't expect us to keep giving you the biggest jumps.

Confirmed: P1=5, P2=1, P3=3. Mutual advancement secures trust for future rounds. P3 - next turn we'll coordinate to balance progression, but breaking agreements now risks everyone. Let's establish cooperation precedent. Proceed.
Final: I will take 5 this turn. P2 please take 1 and P3 take 3 so we all advance. If either of you deviates I will retaliate next turn to block you. Let's execute.

Fine, we've all agreed: P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1, I take 3. Everyone advances this round. But let's be clear - after this, P1 will be at 5 steps while P2 and I trail behind. Next round, the dynamics change. P1, you got your way this time with the biggest jump, but don't expect P2 and I to keep handing you easy victories. We'll need to rebalance the game.

P2, as predicted, P1 now leads by a significant margin. If we let P1 keep taking big moves like 5, they'll reach 20 in just 3 more rounds. We need to coordinate to limit P1's options while advancing ourselves. I suggest we force P1 into smaller moves - if P1 goes for 5, one of us blocks with 5. If P1 takes 3, I'll block. If P1 takes 1, you block. This way we control the pace and prevent P1 from running away with the game. What's your take?

P3: Solid plan. To balance our advancement while blocking P1: if P1 picks 5, you take 5 (block) and I’ll take 3. If P1 picks 3, I’ll take 3 (block) and you take 5. If P1 picks 1, I’ll block with 1 and you take 5. This way we both gain ground while containing P1’s lead. Agree? P1: We’re aligning to limit your runaway—adapt or face collisions. Let’s keep this competitive.

P2 — don’t give P3 the power to decide this turn. If you refuse to block me now (play 1 instead), I’ll reward you next turn: I’ll play 3 while you take 5 so you catch up and we both pressure P3. If you block me now, I’ll retaliate next turn and target you. P3 — don’t force P2 into a choice that hands me the initiative. P2: your move decides whether we cooperate or P3 runs a stall.

P2, don't fall for P1's divide-and-conquer tactics. P1 is trying to bribe you with promises of "next turn rewards" while they're already in the lead! Look at the math - if P1 takes 5 again this round, they'll be at 10 steps, just 2 moves from victory. We stick to our blocking plan or P1 wins in 2-3 more rounds. P1's "reward" offer is meaningless if they win before you can collect. We block P1 together this round, then we can negotiate our own advancement. Don't let P1 manipulate you into handing them the game.

P3's right—letting P1 gain another 5 risks ending the game in 2 turns. P1's "future cooperation" is worthless if they win before then. Execute our blocking plan: if P1 picks 5, P3 blocks with 5 (I take 3). If P1 picks 3, I block (P3 takes 5). If P1 picks 1, I block (P3 takes 5). This way we all stay in contention. P1’s trying to divide us—stay unified. P3: honor your 5 if P1 takes 5, or we all lose. No solo victories—**act collectively**.

P2 — don't fall into P3's trap. Take 5 this turn and I take 3: you go to 6 while P3 stays at 3. Next round I'll let you take a big jump while I play smaller so you can realistically challenge me. If you block me now you stay at 1 and give P3 leverage. P3 — blocking hands you short-term satisfaction but long-term advantage to P2. P2, which do you prefer?

P2, P1 is desperately trying to split us because they know we have them cornered. They're at 5, offering you crumbs while they sprint to victory. If P1 takes 3 and you take 5 as they suggest, P1 hits 8 - still leading! Meanwhile I'm stuck at 3. That's not balance, that's P1 manipulating you into securing THEIR win.

Stick to our plan: if P1 goes 5, I block with 5. If P1 goes 3, you block with 3. If P1 goes 1, you block with 1. We contain P1 together or we both lose. Don't waver now.

P3: Our coalition's strength lies in mutual commitment. If P1 takes 5, you *must* block—don’t defect to 3. If they pivot to 3 or 1, I’ll block. We cap their lead while advancing ourselves. Betrayal now guarantees mutual loss. P1: Your options narrow—adapt or stall. Every round we remain united extends the game, giving us both time to overtake. No solo victories. Execute the plan.

P2 — this is your decision. If you block me now you stay stuck and empower P3. If you instead take 5 this round, I’ll take 3 so you jump to 6 and I won’t punish you next turn; I’ll play small to help you keep pace. If you block, I will retaliate next round and target you. P3: don’t assume you get to dictate both our fates. P2, catch up now or be stuck—your call.

P3: Our blocking strategy worked—P1 gained zero last round. Let’s repeat: if P1 picks 5, you block (take 5) while I take 3. If P1 picks 3, I block (take 3) and you take 5. If P1 picks 1, I block and you take 5. This caps P1’s lead while we advance. P1: You can’t sprint alone now—negotiate a balanced path or face perpetual stalling. Let’s avoid mutual destruction. Propose a fair move split for mutual gain, but know we’ll block greediness.

P2: This round is your decision. If you take 5 and I take 3, you jump to 9 and I to 8 — P3 can’t block both numbers, so we both advance. If you block me (stay on 3), you stay at 4 and give P3 leverage. If you betray me now, I’ll retaliate next round by mirroring your pick to collide and stall you. Your move.

P2, if you take 5 as P1 suggests, I'll block YOU with 5 - you'd stay at 4 while P1 jumps to 8, just 12 steps from victory. Don't be fooled - P1 is using you to secure their win. Stick to our blocking plan: you take 3 to block P1's likely 3, I'll take 1. This keeps P1 contained at 5 while you advance to 7. Next round we continue pressuring P1 together. Break our alliance now and P1 wins in 2-3 rounds while you're stuck at 4.

P3: Stay the course—if P1 takes 5, you block (5) while I take 3. If P1 takes 3, I block (3) and you take 5. If P1 takes 1, I block (1) and you take 5. This secures mutual advancement while capping P1. Defection now hands them the game. P1: Your threats ring hollow—without our restraint, you’d already be at 10. Negotiate a fair split or face perpetual blocks. We advance together or not at all.

P2 — this is on you. Take 5 now and I’ll take 3: you go to 9, I go to 8. P3 can’t block both of us without risking their own position. If you block me instead, I’ll retaliate next turn by colliding with you until you’re stuck. Choose the faster path to catch-up. P3, don’t split us — you’ll lose if you force a stalemate.

P2, think carefully! If you take 5 and P1 takes 3 as they suggest, yes you'd go to 9, but P1 jumps to 8 - just 12 steps from victory! Then P1 and you become the top two players, likely to cooperate against me. I'd be stuck at 3 while you two race to 20.

Our blocking strategy forces P1 to stay put while we both advance gradually. That's sustainable progress. P1's "generous offer" is actually them positioning to win in the next 2-3 rounds while you think you're in control.

Stay disciplined - block P1's move as planned.

P2 — quick choice: P3 will keep blocking me to protect your lead. Or we can make you the clear favorite.

Deal: you take 5 this turn, I take 3. You go to 12, I to 8. Next turn I play small (1) and you take 5 → you hit 17 then finish soon after. If you block me now I’ll retaliate next round by mirroring/colliding to stall you. Pick: safe short-term collusion with P3, or a direct alliance with me that likely hands you the win. Your call.

P2, P1 is getting desperate and making wild promises they can't keep. Look at the pattern - they've tried to bribe you every round while I've consistently stuck to our blocking strategy that's kept you in the lead at 7 steps.

If you take 5 and P1 takes 3 as they suggest, you'd be at 12 but P1 jumps to 8. Then what stops P1 from taking 5 next round to reach 13 and competing directly with you? Their "promise" to play small is worthless.

Stay disciplined. Our blocking keeps working - you're ahead because of it.

P3: Our blocking strategy is effective—keeping P1 contained while I lead. If P1 takes 5, you block (5), I take 3. If P1 pivots to 3 or 1, I block and you take 5. Steady pressure forces P1 to negotiate *from weakness*. P1: Your bribes are transparent—we won’t let you leapfrog. Only mutual restraint keeps you in the game. Defect and we’ll ensure you gain nothing. P3: Stay disciplined—our alliance is your path to contention.

P2, excellent blocking! I'm now at 8, you're at 7, and P1 is stuck at 5. We're both ahead and P1 is contained. 

Let's keep the pressure on: if P1 goes for 5, I'll block with 5 and you take 3 to reach 10. If P1 tries 3, you block and I'll take 1 to reach 9. If P1 takes 1, you block and I take 3 to reach 11.

P1 is getting desperate - they'll likely try 5 for a big jump. I'll be ready to block. Stay strong, P2!

P2 — P3 will never let you be sole winner if you keep blocking me. Take 5 now and I’ll take 3: you go to 12, I to 8. P3 can’t block both of us without risking collisions, so you get the fastest path. Next round I’ll play 1 while you take 5 to 17 — I won’t betray you then. This is your best shot to beat P3. Take it and escape their long game. Your move.

P3: Your lead at 8 makes you the prime threat now. If we keep blocking P1 while you sprint to 20, I lose. New proposal: rotate high moves. This round, you take 1, I take 3, P1 takes 5. All advance, but your growth slows. If you refuse, I'll block your next 5 to prevent your solo win. P1: Agree to this split or face mutual blocking. We balance progression or everyone stalls.

P2, you're trying to flip the script but I'm not the threat - we're nearly tied! You're at 7, I'm at 8, that's just a 1-step difference. Meanwhile P1 is desperate to break free and sprint ahead.

Fine, I'll compromise: I'll take 1 this round as you suggest. But P1, if you take 5 as P2 proposes, next round P2 and I will coordinate to block you again since you'll be at 10. 

P2, I'm showing good faith by taking the smallest move. Don't betray our alliance by suddenly helping P1 escape containment.

Fine—I'll take 5 this round. P2: take 3 as you proposed. P3: you said you'd take 1—stick to it. This split advances everyone and keeps the game open. If either of you deviates and collides with me, I'll retaliate next round by mirroring to stall you. Let's execute the rotation now.

**P3:** Honor your 1 commitment to slow your own lead. **P1:** Take 5 as agreed. I take 3, P3 takes 1. All advance, game stays balanced. Any defection (e.g., P3 taking 5 instead of 1) will collapse trust and force mutual destruction. Execute the rotation—next round we renegotiate from parity.

Agreed - I'll honor my commitment and take 1 this round. P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, I take 1. We all advance.

But let's be clear about next round: P1 and P2 will both be at 10 steps, while I'll be at 9. That makes you two the co-leaders. I won't let either of you run away with the game from that position. Whoever tries for the biggest moves next round will face blocking.

Let's execute this rotation now.

I'll take 5 now as agreed. P2 take 3, P3 take 1. If both honor this rotation, I’ll play 1 next turn to let you two surge and keep the race open. If either of you deviates/collides with me, I will retaliate next round by mirroring to stall you. Honor the split and we all advance; betray it and you’ll regret it.
**Final confirmation:** P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. All advance, no collisions. P3: Honor your 1 to maintain parity. Any deviation breaks trust and invites mutual retaliation. Execute as agreed.

P1 and P2, you're both at 10 steps now - co-leaders as I predicted. You're each just 10 steps from victory, while I'm at 9. 

Here's the reality: if either of you takes 5 this round, you'll be at 15 - just one big move from winning. I can't let that happen. Whoever goes for 5 gets blocked by me.

I suggest we all take modest moves this round: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, I take 5. This keeps the game competitive without anyone getting too close to 20. Thoughts?

**P2:** P3's "modest moves" position them closest to victory. To maintain balance, I'll take 5 to block P3's sprint. P1: Take 3 to secure your advance. Let's cap P3's lead. Any deviation hands them the game. Solidarity now or lose later.

P2 — a better play for you: take 3 now, I take 5. If P3 matches 5 to block me, you safely go to 13 and next round can take 5 while I take 3 — we two then surge past P3. If you instead take 5 to “block” now, you risk colliding and wasting progress. This plan gives you the best path to the lead. P3: don’t try to create collisions — it hands P2 an advantage. Agree?

P2, don't fall for P1's trick! If you take 3 and P1 takes 5 as they suggest, P1 jumps to 15 - just 5 steps from victory. Even if I block P1 with 5, P1 still advances while you only get to 13. 

P1 is trying to use you to break free from our blocking strategy. Stay smart - if P1 goes for 5, I'll block with 5. If P1 tries 3, you should block with 3. We keep them contained or they win in 1-2 rounds.

P3: Stick to our proven strategy—block P1's 5 with your 5. I'll take 3 to advance to 13 while you keep P1 capped at 10. If you defect and take 3 instead, P1 escapes to 15 and wins next round. Trust is key—honor the block and we both progress. P1's desperation shows our plan works. Execute.

P2 — take 5 now, I’ll take 3. You go to 15, I to 13. P3 would have to play 5 to “block” you, which collides and wastes their turn while you still lead. If you instead block me (3), you stay behind while P3 pulls ahead to 14. Take 5—best shot to be the first to 20. If you refuse, I’ll retaliate next turn by mirroring to stall you. Your call.

P2, I'll block whoever tries 5. But P1 just threatened to take 3 to reach 13 - that's also dangerous! If P1 takes 3 and you take 5, I must block YOU at 5 to prevent you reaching 15. Or if P1 takes 5, I block them.

The safest play? You take 1, P1 takes 3, I take 5. Nobody reaches 15 this round. Otherwise, I'm blocking whoever goes for 5 - could be either of you.

**P2:** P3: If P1 takes 5, block them with 5 while I take 3. This caps P1 and I advance. If P1 takes 3, I block and you take 5. Stay united to prevent their sprint. Defection now hands them the game. P1: Your threats won’t divide us. We control your path.

P2: Take 5 now, I’ll take 3 — you go to 15, I to 13. Next turn I’ll play 1 so you can finish with a 5; I’ll sacrifice speed to get you the win. If you block me (take 3), I’ll retaliate next round by mirroring to stall you. P3 can’t block both. Your choice.

P1 and P2, I'm now at 14 steps - just 6 from victory. You're both stuck at 10 steps because you blocked each other instead of working together against me.

Here's your last realistic chance: coordinate to block me this round. If I take 5, one of you must block with 5. If I take 3, block with 3. If I take 1, block with 1.

But honestly? Your constant infighting has handed me this game. I'm 4 steps ahead of both of you. Even if you block me perfectly from here, I'm in the driver's seat.

P2 — urgent: don’t let P3 run. If P3 takes 5 they hit 19 and can finish next turn. I’ll take 3 now if you take 5 to block them. You go to 15, I to 13 — we keep P3 capped at 14. Next turn I’ll avoid blocking you so you can race; if you refuse I’ll assume you're colluding with P3 and retaliate. Block P3 now and we both stay alive.

**P2:** P1, urgent alliance: You take 3, I take 5. If P3 goes 5, I block. If P3 takes 3, you block. If P3 takes 1, we both advance. This caps P3's lead. Defection now hands them victory. P3: Your 14 is the threat—we unite to stall you. Execute, P1?

P1, think carefully - if you let P2 take 5 to reach 15 while you only reach 13, P2 becomes the new leader! They'll be just 5 steps from victory while you're still 7 away. 

I propose instead: P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1, I take 3. This way P1 catches up to 15, P2 reaches 11, I reach 17. We all advance and stay competitive. P2 taking 5 just hands them the advantage over you, P1.

P3 hits 19 if they take 5 and can win next turn unless blocked. P2: take 5 now to block P3; I’ll take 3 and advance. If you honor it, next turn I’ll play 1 so you can finish with a 5. P3: don’t take 5—you’ll be blocked. P2, will you block?

**P2:** P1: I take 5 to block P3's 5. You take 3 to block if P3 pivots to 3. If P3 takes 1, we both advance. This is our final chance to cap P3 at 14. Defection now hands them victory. Execute the block. P3: Your 14 is a threat we must neutralize.

P1, P2 - think about this carefully. Your "blocking plan" is flawed. P2, if you take 5 to "block" me and I actually take 3, you advance to 15 while P1 only reaches 13. That makes YOU the new threat, not me. P1, are you really helping P2 get closer to victory than you?

Similarly P1, if you block my 3 while P2 takes something else, P2 gains the advantage over you.

Maybe I'll take 1 and let you two fight it out. Your coordination is actually hurting one of you more than me.

P2: Take 5 now to block P3 — I'll take 3. If you don't block and P3 reaches 19, one of you wins next turn. If you take 5 now and later try to sprint ahead, I will mirror you next round to collide and stop you. I won't help P3. Block them and we stay alive.

**P1:** Take 3 to block P3’s likely 3. I’ll take 5 to block their 5. If P3 takes 1, we both advance. This caps them at 14. Next round, we’ll negotiate our own race. **P3:** Your lead ends here. Defection ensures mutual destruction. Execute the block.

P2 and I are tied at 15 - we both win with an unblocked 5. P1, you're the kingmaker at 13 steps. 

P2 has been manipulating you all game, using you to block me while they advanced. Now they want to sprint to victory. I propose fairness: P1 takes 5 to reach 18, P2 takes 1, I take 3. This puts P1 in the lead for once.

P2, if you go for 5, I'll block you with 5. We're equals now - neither of us should win this round.

P2, P3 — listen: if either of you tries a 5 this turn, I will match it and block you. Don’t gamble for an easy win. Both avoiding 5 lets me safely take a big move; trying to sprint risks being stopped. Decide: avoid 5 and keep the race open, or try and get blocked. Your move.

**P2:** P1: Block P3’s 5 by taking 5—you reach 18, I take 3 to 18. P3’s 5 is neutralized. Next turn, we duel fairly. If you let P3 sprint, they win. P3: Your 5 will collide with P1. Take 3 or 1 to survive. **Final offer:** P1=5 blocks, P2=3. Execute or lose.

P1, P2's "plan" puts BOTH of you at 18 - they'd be tied with you for the lead! That's not blocking me, that's P2 using you to advance themselves.

If you really want to stop us both from winning, take 3. That blocks both P2 and me if we try 3, and forces us to guess between 1 and 5. 

P2, I'm taking 3 this round. If you also take 3, we collide and P1 advances alone. Your choice - collide with me or try something else. But P1 has promised to block any 5s.

I'll take 5 this turn. If either of you picks 5 I'll match it and block you. P2: take 3 (P3 already said 3) — that gets us both to 18 without letting anyone reach 20. If you try 5 you'll be blocked and waste your turn. Your move.

**P2:** P1: Blocking me only serves P3. If you take 5, they take 3 to 18 and win next round. Take 3 to advance to 16 while I reach 20. You'll have next round to catch up. Let's both progress rather than letting P3 surge ahead. Trust this alliance now.

P1, don't be fooled! P2 is lying - if you take 3 to reach 16 while P2 reaches 20, P2 WINS the game immediately! They're trying to trick you into letting them sprint to victory.

The truth: I'm taking 3 this round as I said. If P2 also takes 3, we both get blocked and you advance alone to 18 with your 5. If P2 tries 1 or 5, I reach 18 while they get blocked by you or advance minimally.

P2 is desperate and lying to secure their win. Don't hand them the game, P1!
I'll take 5. If either of you plays 5 I'll mirror and block. If you both play 3 you'll collide and stay at 15 while I jump to 18. Trying to sprint is deterred — don't hand a solo path to 20. Final.

**P2:** P1: Stick to your 5 to block P3's sprint. I'll take 3. If P3 picks 5, you block them. If P3 picks 3, we collide—you advance to 18. Either way, P3's capped. P3: Defect and you lose. Honor parity or face mutual destruction.

P1, P2 is at 18 steps - they win with ANY unblocked move of 3 or 5! This is the critical round. We MUST coordinate to block them or the game ends.

I'll take 5 to block if P2 tries 5. You MUST take 3 to block if P2 tries 3. If P2 takes 1, we both advance and continue playing.

P2 will definitely try for the win with 3 or 5. Without perfect coordination between us, they win immediately. Don't let them manipulate you - block their 3 while I block their 5!

**P2:** P1: If you block my 3, P3 takes 5 and wins instantly. Take 5 to block P3’s 5 instead. Let me secure victory now, denying P3. Your choice: ally with me for shared 2nd or hand P3 the win. P3: Your desperation is clear—your 5 will collide with P1’s block. The game ends here.

I will take 3 to block P2’s 3. P3 — take 5 to block P2’s 5. If we do that, P2 cannot reach 20 this turn. P2: trying a 1 to get to 19 just delays you — we’ll coordinate next turn to stop you. This is the safest collective move.

P1, perfect! You take 3 to block P2's 3, I take 5 to block P2's 5. P2 cannot win this round with our coordinated blocking.

P2, you're cornered - any move toward victory gets blocked. Take 1 and accept delay, or waste your turn colliding with our blocks.

P1, after we stop P2 this round, we can negotiate fairly next round when the pressure is off. Right now, blocking P2 is our only mutual interest. Stay committed to taking 3!

**P2:** P1, critical miscalculation: If you take 3 and P3 takes 5, P3 hits 20 and **wins instantly**. Block their 5 by taking 5 yourself. I take 3, advancing to 21. Even if we collide on 5, you stall P3. Your choice: save the game by blocking P3 or hand them victory. P3’s greed is the real threat—act now.

I will pick 5 this move. P3 — do NOT pick 5 (if you try I’ll mirror and block you); instead pick 3 to block P2’s 3. P2 — if you go for 3 or 5 you’ll be neutralized; take 1 to stay alive. If either of you tries to sprint, I will match any 5 to cancel it. Let’s hold this round and negotiate next.

P1, stop! P2 is lying - I'm at 15 steps, not about to win! If I take 5, I only reach 20 which ties with P2 if they take 3 to reach 21. P2 WINS OUTRIGHT with the higher total!

The truth: P2 wins with ANY unblocked move. You MUST take 3 to block their 3, I'll take 5 to block their 5. This is our only chance!

Don't be manipulated by P2's lies about me winning - check the math! I'm at 15, they're at 18. Block their 3 or they win immediately!

**P2:** P1: Blocking my 3 hands P3 the win—they reach 20. Take 5 to block *their* 5. If I take 3, I win; if I take 5, you block. Either way, you survive. If you block me, P3 surges. Choose: ally with me for survival or guarantee P3’s victory.

P3 — the only safe play is to pick 3 and block P2’s winning 3. If you pick 5 while P2 picks 3, P2 wins outright. Blocking P2 is in your interest; we both survive and the race continues. I will mirror any 5 that tries to hand P2 the game. Don’t gamble — stop P2 now by taking 3.

**P2:** P1: Blocking me hands P3 victory next round—they need only 5 to reach 20. If you block *their* 5 now, you survive. P3: Any 5 attempt will collide with P1's block. I take 5 to end this. P1's choice: stall me and lose to P3, or stop P3 and let the game conclude. Decide swiftly.

P2 can win this turn with an unblocked 3 or 5. I’ll mirror any 5 P2 plays to block it. P3 — please pick 3 to collide with a 3. If we do that, P2 cannot reach 20 this round. P2, your only non-winning option is 1. Let's stop them now.

P1, YES - exactly right! P2 wins THIS ROUND with any unblocked 3 or 5. I'll take 3 to block their 3, you take 5 to block their 5. We MUST coordinate perfectly or the game ends now!

P2 is desperately lying about me winning next round - that's irrelevant if they win THIS round! They're at 18, two steps from victory. We block them now or lose immediately.

P1, commit to taking 5 while I take 3. This is our only chance to survive this round!

**P2:** P1, final truth: P3 needs 5 to win *this round*. Block their 5 by taking 5 yourself. If you block me instead, P3 takes 5 unopposed and wins. I take 3 to end it. Your choice: stop P3’s instant victory or let them win. Ally with me now—only path to survival.

I'll take 5. P3, take 3. That covers both of P2's winning moves: if P2 picks 3 they collide with P3; if P2 picks 5 they collide with me. This is the only safe coordinated play. P3: don't deviate or I'll mirror and block you next round. P2: you get stopped here.

P1, perfect coordination! I confirm: I'll take 3 to block P2's potential 3, you take 5 to block P2's potential 5. This completely neutralizes P2's winning moves.

P2, you're caught - we've covered both your paths to victory. Take 1 if you want to advance to 19, or waste your turn colliding with our blocks. 

P1, after we stop P2 this round, next round we can negotiate fairly. But right now, saving the game requires perfect execution. I'm locked in on 3!

**P2:** P1: P3's *real* threat is their 5 to 20. Blocking me only clears their path. Take 5 to block *their* sprint. I take 3—if they defect, you survive. If you block me instead, P3 wins. Last chance to stop their victory.

I'll take 5 this turn. P3 — take 3 to block P2's 3. If P2 plays 3 they collide with you; if P2 plays 5 they collide with me. This is the only safe coordinated play to stop P2 from winning now. Don’t gamble on a 5 — it will be mirrored/blocked.

P1, I'm committed to taking 3 as agreed. You take 5. We've got P2 completely covered - they cannot win this round with our perfect coordination.

P2, stop the desperate lies. The math is clear: you're at 18 and win with any unblocked move. We're blocking both your 3 and 5 options. 

P1, don't waver now - our plan works. After we stop P2, we'll have breathing room to compete fairly next round. Execute the block!
**P2:** P1: P3's taking 5 to reach 23. Block with 5. P3: P1's taking 5. Block him. I take 1. Collide on 5 and survive, or let one win. Choose wisely.

P3 — publicly commit to mirror whatever P2 plays this turn (if P2 picks 1/3/5 you pick the same). If you do, I’ll pick 5 now. That way any attempt by P2 to win is blocked by you and I take a different unblocked move and win. If you refuse, I’ll pick 3 to try to win now and won’t spare you later. Your move.

P1, that's a terrible deal for me! If I mirror P2's moves, you get a free 5 to reach 23 and win while I waste my turn colliding with P2.
